item.title: First Monster Hunter Wilds Title Update Showcase Set for Next Week
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/monster-hunter-wilds-title-update-showcase-march-25th

Capcom has announced when the first Monster Hunter Wilds Title Update showcase will air, giving you a glimpse of some of the new stuff coming to the phenomenally popular action RPG as part of its inaugural update.

As revealed in a Steam news post earlier today, Capcom will unveil Title Update 1, which is due to arrive sometime in April, on March 25th. You can catch it at around 7am Pacific (that's about 10am Eastern and around 2pm GMT).

The showcase will see Monster Hunter producer Ryozo Tsujimoto revealing more about what's coming as part of Title Update 1, including returning monster Mizutsune, as well as "a host of other new additions", according to Capcom.

If previous Monster Hunter Title Update showcases are anything to go by, we'll probably get some more endgame activities for Monster Hunter Wilds as part of its first update, plus more cosmetics and perhaps a little more paid DLC to tempt you.

Just in case you're not familiar with it, Monster Hunter Wilds is the latest game in Capcom's Monster Hunter series of action RPGs. The game features a more direct narrative focus than its predecessors, but at its core, it's still built around slaying monsters and using their parts to upgrade your gear.

The game has proven phenomenally popular since launch, racking up eight million sales in its first three days and breaking records for both the series and Capcom as a whole on Steam.

Despite the fact that it was released on the very last day of February, Monster Hunter Wilds instantly topped the month's chart for best-selling games according to analyst firm Circana, so it's safe to say Capcom has a hit on its hands (talons?) with this one.

Monster Hunter Wilds' first Title Update showcase airs on March 25th at 7am Pacific (10am Eastern, 2pm GMT). You can buy the game right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and you can read our Tyler's review right here.

item.title: Split Fiction Movie Reportedly In the Works, Bidding War Underway
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/split-fiction-movie-report

A new report has emerged which claims that a Split Fiction movie is in the works, and that several major Hollywood studios are already engaged in a bidding war over the rights to said movie.

According to Variety, media company Story Kitchen is currently scouting writers and directors, as well as cast members, for the project. You might also recognize Story Kitchen's name from the likes of the Dredge movie, which was announced last year, as well as the upcoming It Takes Two movie adaptation.

Citing "sources at the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in San Francisco", Variety says that a number of "top Hollywood studios" are currently making offers for the rights to the Split Fiction movie, although it sounds like nothing has been decided yet.

Given Split Fiction's close focus on gameplay, I'm having a bit of a hard time imagining how a movie would work; I can only imagine some of the game's uniqueness will be lost in the transition. Still, it's testament to Split Fiction's popularity that a movie adaptation is already underway.

Of course, the movie makes a lot of sense from a financial perspective, too. After all, Split Fiction managed to reach two million sales in a single week, so creating more media based around the IP is sound logic.

It's the same logic that drove Story Kitchen to create the It Takes Two adaptation, and that game recently passed the 20 million sales mark. It just remains to be seen whether Split Fiction's gaming audience would also be interested in a non-interactive version of the story.

In case you're unfamiliar with Split Fiction, it's the latest co-op adventure from It Takes Two and A Way Out developer Hazelight, led by Josef Fares.

The game casts you and your co-op buddy as Mio and Zoe, two writers who must learn to work together when they're thrust into a diabolical machine that threatens to steal all of their ideas.

You can check out Split Fiction right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. Make sure to read our Erren's review to get the lowdown on whether it's worth your time or not (spoiler: she very much thinks it is).
